The class is a fun way to learn about the history of African dance art and musicââits roots and traditions, and how it became prevalent in the west, NY especially. It's a very relaxed class, and good to take if you've already got a few tough courses for the semester.

I would highly highly highly highly recommend this class. It's so stress-free. You only have to study or work maybe 4-6 days out of the entire semester. Lectures are very relaxed. Not many people would go, but those that did were rewarded by watching the amazing Master T dance with football players. The incredible thing about this class is that you actually learn stuff. Shocking. You could miss lectures to work on other classes or sleep in and then cram the day before for the tests and do very well.

If you don't take this class, you're crazy. Not only is it incredibly low stress, but its also incredibly fun. You dance in class, play drums, look at awesome artwork, and are constantly entertained by Master T's antics. A lot of people take this class, skip every lecture, cram for the tests, and pull off okay grades.. sometimes even good grades. They run around, laughing off Mambo as a classic gut class, even though they most likely brought up the bottom of the class with B's and C's. Thats great for them. I would recommend actually going. if you're looking to relax for an hour a day, engage, have some fun with it, and zone out to what is practically a comedy routine put on by master T at 11:30 every day, then you are rewarded when you have almost no extra preparation to do for the exams. I just laughed, danced, chanted, and sang my way to an A, and all I had to do was show up and be entertained for an hour. For all you science, econ, and math majors.. grab the free HU creditAgain, you have to be crazy not to take this class. I will remember it for the rest of my life.
Yes. The class will change your view of the world and shape your knowledge around African culture. Also disproves the notion that Africans are barbaric and primitive.

Honestly the best way to get an A in the course, regardless of who your TA is, is the following: First and foremost, do not use the team notes that are passed around. The TA's are on the lookout for them and immediately give you a lower grade just for using them. Secondly, come up with a good thesis. The exam questions are extremely general (e.g. "Describe the black visual tradition and how you know it when you see it or hear it?"or "What have you learned since the last exam"), so a good thesis is pretty easy to do. In fact, if you start studying early, you can probably ask the TA about how your thesis sounds. Once you have a pretty good thesis, come up with three examples from the course, so far, that support your thesis. Again, you do not need to describe everything you learned, which is a common mistake most students in the class make. Write a paragraph for each example using your notes, internet, and the book about each example, and memorize 2 quotes for each example for a total of 6 quotes from the book. It is also helpful to drop a few people in there. You definitely don't have to read the whole book to pick out some intellectual sounding quotes. For each paragraph refer back to how this example relates to your thesis. Finally, add another paragraph with few tidbits that he says in the review session (e.g. list the five african tribes with descriptions; name 7 artists), and use some book quotes. Last, but not least, put a conclusion. In essence, you should prepare an essay before you even show up to class and memorize it.

This is a very interesting and fun class in which Dr. Robert Farris Thompson(aka Master T)explores the music and art traditions of different African tribes; the general traits of the African art and music tradition; and finally how those traits have been transplanted to the "New World" and how they can be seen in dances like Mambo, Tango, Bomba, Hip Hop and many others. Throughout the course, Master T invited a couple of speakers to demonstrate things like Capoeira or Bomba. Master T focuses a lot on demonstrations-whether it be singing or dancing, and he calls out people in class to do these things. His explanation: You won't remember a lot of the things you learn in college, but you'll remember that. Master T is very passionate about this subject and an expert in the field. Though you may not agree with everything being taught, it's an interesting perspective and this is a class worth taking if you just want to explore and have fun while doing it. Nevertheless, despite popular opinion, I would not regard this as a gut class. You'll have to work for your grade.Strength: Passionate Professor, Engaging through DemonstrationsWeakness: Lack of Structure in the Coursevery Ambiguous Questions for both the Midterm and FinalMay be at loss in knowing what to study for the midterm and final

YES. New York Mambo is an experience that you owe it to yourself to have while you are at Yale. Master T is both hilarious, but also really very brilliant, and you'll learn things that are very important to know about that you can't get anywhere else. On the one hand ,you'll crack up every class and enjoy going to Mambo more than any other class (and please do yourself a favor and actually come), but you'll also leave with a newfound appreciation for African and African-American culture, and knowing something more about the arts (music, dance, art) than you did before. It's also very little work, and is an amazing way to fill out a schedule, especially if your other classes are intense or pretty heavy-duty. Do yourself a favor and just take it.
